awd_titl_txt: A next generation instrumented buoy for Lake Annie, Archbold Biological Station
awd_abstract_narration:
Archbold Biological Station (Archbold www.archbold-station.org) is a biological field station in Florida dedicated to long-term ecological research and education. Archbold owns and manages a globally significant scrub preserve including the beautiful 90-acre, Lake Annie. Studies of Lake Annie are recognized globally for providing insights into the history of lakes in the southern USA (40,000-year sediment record), long-term (30-year) ecological and chemical sampling, and a moored buoy (since 2008) with sensors measuring chemical and physical conditions at the lake surface. This NSF award will support deployment of a new "next-generation profiling buoy" equipped with many more sensors (climate, oxygen, pH, algae and chlorophyll, temperature, water color, light, heat, solar radiation, and CO2) than Archbold's old buoy. Most of the new sensors will be "profiling", or constantly moving up and down, gathering data from the lake surface to the bottom of the lake at 67'. For deep lakes, like Lake Annie, continuous data from top to bottom are critical to measure features such as the "metabolism" of the whole lake, or how much energy (growth) is occurring (such as plant or algae production) versus energy loss such as via respiration.  Lake scientists, especially those engaged with the Global Lakes Ecological Observatory Network or GLEON, plan to combine Lake Annie data with data from other lakes around the world, allowing them to answer questions such as how lakes of different sizes, latitude, and surrounding land use are responding differently to changing conditions. The new Lake Annie buoy will provide research and education opportunities for visiting scientists and college classes, training for graduate students and interns, online data and remote data access, as well as a new module for Archbold's K-12 program, and expanded offerings for public programs including citizen science, lake association groups, science-arts events, and public seminars. A new interpretive sign will be installed at Lake Annie as well as increased sharing of lake science via a new video, Archbold social media, and enewsletters, 


This award will deploy a next generation, highly-instrumented profiling buoy at Lake Annie, a significant upgrade from the existing old buoy. The extensive (2 million record) Lake Annie buoy dataset is already available online via CUAHSI and this award will further expand Archbold's ability to deliver data for collaborations in lake science, especially with the Global Lakes Ecological Observatory Network GLEON. Lake scientists around the world plan to conduct analysis, synthesis, and modeling using Lake Annie data. Two new sondes and associated sensors will allow for continuous profiling of D.O., pH, total algae and chlorophyll, temperature, conductivity, fDOM, and light, as well as surface measures of meteorology, heat fluxes, solar radiation, and CO2. The new instrumentation will expand Archbold's role in cross-lake studies in areas such as: (i) lake metabolism by adding new measures of CO2 and D.O profiles; (ii) controls of high frequency variance in algal production and colored organic material by adding depth-resolved fluorescence sensors in a low-chlorophyll, oligotrophic humic end-member lake; (iii) spatiotemporal environmental heterogeneity in controlling our highly spatiotemporally variable phytoplankton dynamics, a feature of subtropical lakes; and (iv) climate and physical modeling through new measurements of mixing, heat flux, and solar radiation. The new buoy will also allow more flexible maintenance, enhance access to real-time data, and expand Archbold's role linking field stations with lake research networks such as GLEON and NEON.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
As a result of this NSF Field Stations and Marine Laboratories FSML award, in 2022 Archbold deployed a fully instrumented profiling buoy on Lake Annie at Archbold Biological Station to increase support for research and education. Archbold, celebrating its 80th year in 2021, is a large not-for-profit scientific research, education, and conservation organization located in the Headwaters of the Everglades in Central Florida (www.archbold-station.org). Lake Annie is one of the most important research lakes in the world with 88 publications derived from avried datasets including sediment cores dating back more than 44,000 years, monthly sampling for four decades, and hourly samples from the previous surface buoy. The profiling buoy deployed under this award has greatly increased the frequency of data collection at Lake Annie with continuous surface measurements and twice hourly profiles from the lake surface to 65' deep.  The new buoy, designed by the company FlyDog, features a climate station, continuous profiling sonde with multiple sensors, surface sonde with similar sensors, as well as surface measures of energy fluxes and CO2.

In terms of intellectual merit, the data collected from the new buoy will facilitate broad new areas of research from Lake Annie. First, CO2 measurements will contribute to global studies of lake metabolism, carbon gas exchange, greenhouse gas models, and climate modeling. Second, continuous oxygen profiles will enable calculations of ecosystem 'respiration' (a measure of lake health). Third, new continuous chlorophyll/total algae profiles from Lake Annie will increase understanding of chlorophyll drivers (algal production) in subtropical low nutrient lakes and better explain the 'patchiness' of chlorophyll and algae/plankton production. Finally, mixing of energy fluxes from Lake Annie will help fill the data gap for subtropical lakes in the global General Lake Model.  Archbold intends to contribute towards collaborative research projects in these areas with the working groups of the Global Lakes Ecological Observatory Network GLEON. Archbold has implemented secure communications to stream data every 15 minutes from the buoy. Buoy sampling frequency and other data instructions can be modified remotely for events such as hurricanes. Streamed data are now available through Archbold's KISTERS environmental data portal for staff and collaborators and the plan is to post online in searchable portals such as CUAHSI as QAQC is completed.

Some broader impacts of the buoy deployment, specifically public presentations and events, were reduced during the period of this award because of COVID restrictions. However, interpretive signage has been developed for the gazebo at the lake, three videos were produced about Lake Annie (available on Archbold's Youtube channel), and multiple online newsletter articles, blogs, and social media posts were produced. It is planned that Archbold staff of 50, research interns, and visiting investigators as well as future professional meetings and conferences and visiting college classes will have increased access to learn about research at Lake Annie. 14 scientific publications were published about Lake Annie (out of a total of 88) during the period of this award although none yet are directly derived from the new buoy data. In addition to enhancing lake science, the data collected from the new buoy will be shared continuously with Florida state agencies who use Lake Annie as a reference for undisturbed conditions in Florida lake environments. As an NSF FSML infrastructure improvement award, and with the buoy deployment only completed in 2022, there have been no direct research outcomes funded by this award to date, but Archbold research and education activities focused on Lake Annie will be enhanced for years as a result of this support.


Last Modified: 12/28/2022
Modified by: Hilary Swain

Image
  • A new profiling buoy was deployed on Lake Annie, Archbold Biological Station in 2022.
    Kevin Main, Archbold
    Public Domain
    Hilary Swain
    Lake Annie Buoy
